titleStmt.title: Effects of elevated ammonium on the transcriptome of the stony coral Pocillopora damicornis

analytic.title: Effects of elevated ammonium on the transcriptome of the stony coral Pocillopora damicornis

biblStruct.note: Received 16 June 2016 Received in revised form 25 July 2016 Accepted 17 August 2016

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Eutrophication Environmental stress Transcriptome Adaption Coral Marine Pollution Bulletin 114 (2017) 46-52

abstract.p: The survival of corals worldwide has been seriously threatened by eutrophication events concomitant with the increase in ocean pollution. In the present study, whole transcriptomes of the stony coral Pocillopora damicornis exposed to elevated ammonium were sequenced. A total of 121,366,983 pair-end reads were obtained, and 209,337 genes were assembled, including 42,399 coral-derived and 54,874 zooxanthella-derived genes. Further, a comparison of the control versus stress group revealed 6572 differentially expressed genes. For 1015 significantly upregulated genes, 24 GO terms were overrepresented, among which 3 terms related to apoptosis and cell death induction included one caspase, five bcl-2-like proteins, and two tumor necrosis factor receptor superfamily member genes. For 5557 significantly downregulated genes, the top 10 overrepresented terms were related to metabolism and signal transduction. These results indicate that apoptosis and cell death could be induced under elevated ammonium, suggesting that metabolic regulation and signal transduction might be involved in the reconstruction of the coral-zooxanthellae symbiotic balance in the stony coral P. damicornis.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Reef-building stony coral is a fundamental pillar for biologically and economically important coral reef ecosystems (Yamashita et al., 2014). Stony corals can effloresce in oligotrophic tropical seas, depending on the elaborate coral-algal symbiosis. In this symbiosis, stony corals provide carbon dioxide for the photosynthesis of the engaged zooxanthellae, while zooxanthellae as symbionts supply photosynthetic products to stony corals (Shinzato et al., 2011). On the basis of this symbiotic relationship, coral reefs are known to be among the world's most productive ecosystems and contain a remarkable diversity of species growing on limited surfaces (Karlson et al., 2004). However, the survival and reproduction of stony corals have been threatened by environmental and anthropogenic aggressions in recent years (Abram et al., 2003;Cerrano et al., 2013;Feuillassier et al., 2014).

Recent global climate change and human activities have accelerated seawater temperature rise, ocean acidification, and eutrophication events; these conditions have ultimately threatened the survival of corals and the sustainability of existing coral reefs worldwide (Bellwood et al., 2004;Seemann et al., 2014). Rapid increase in the atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration, driven by global warming and ocean acidification, is likely to be a serious threat to coral survival (Hoegh-Guldberg et al., 2007). The corals growing under this stress condition are more susceptible to pathogenic microorganisms, which can lead to coral diseases and bleaching (Mydlarz et al., 2009;Weis, 2008). In addition, eutrophication is an easily overlooked factor that threatens coral survival. Eutrophication of coastal waters has recently emerged as a crisis because of dumping of domestic and industrial wastewater containing abundant nutrients directly into the sea (Cheevaporn and Menasveta, 2003;Fabricius, 2011;Fabricius, 2005). Large-scale chronic eutrophication obstructs the survival of corals and the sustainability of coral reef (Bell et al., 2014). Even worse, eutrophication has been considered as a major cause of decline in coral reef (Szmant, 2002).

Eutrophication can exert harmful effects on the survival and reproduction of stony corals; therefore, the effects of dissolved inorganic nutrients as important components of eutrophication have often been studied (Dubinsky and Stambler, 1996;Koop et al., 2001;Lam et al., 2015). Previous studies have reported that high levels of dissolved inorganic nitrogen and phosphorus could cause significant physiological changes in stony corals, including reduction in calcification, higher concentrations of zooxanthellae, and potentially higher rates of coral diseases (Bruno et al., 2003;Marubini and Davies, 1996;Stambler et al., 1994). It has been thought that exposure to dissolved inorganic nutrients alters the energy and nutrient transfer between zooxanthellae and coral, but do not directly inhibit the growth of individual coral colonies (Fabricius, 2005). Furthermore, eutrophication can affect the embryogenesis and ontogenesis of stony corals. High levels of inorganic nutrients can reduce fertilization success, egg viability, and polyspermic block in the coral Platygyra acuta (Lam et al., 2015); impair fertilization success and embryo development in the corals Acropora longicyathus and Goniastrea aspera (Harrison and Ward, 2001); and reduce ciliary activity (motility) and settlement rate in the larvae of the coral Diploria strigosa (Bassim and Sammarco, 2003). The effects of eutrophication on coral survival and reproduction have been ascertained at the individual and cellular levels, but their underlying molecular mechanisms remain unclear.

Pocillopora damicornis is a common reef-building stony coral found on tropical coral reefs throughout the Indo-Pacific region. In recent years, the next-generation sequencing technology has emerged as a cutting-edge approach for high-throughput sequence determination and has been applied to greatly enrich the transcriptome resources of corals (Moya et al., 2012;Polato et al., 2011;Shinzato et al., 2014;Sun et al., 2013;Vidal-Dupiol et al., 2014;Vidal-Dupiol et al., 2013). In the present study, the transcriptome response of the coral P. damicornis was investigated after exposure to elevated ammonium through the next-generation sequencing technology; this study could pave a new way to further understand the modulation mechanism of stress response and environmental adaption to eutrophication in stony corals. The purposes of this study were to (1) identify the transcripts from the coral P. damicornis, (2) determine the differentially expressed genes of the coral after exposure to elevated ammonium, and (3) investigate the possible coral physiological changes resulting from these differentially expressed genes to understand the potential molecular regulation mechanisms of eutrophication stress.

div.head: Corals
div.p: Samples of the stony coral P. damicornis were collected from the coral reef in Wenchang, Hainan Province, China, and maintained in seawater at 28°C for 2 weeks before processing.

div.head: Elevated ammonium treatment
div.p: To avoid the potential effect of interindividual variability and genetic background, the treatment experiment was performed using clones of the same P. damicornis isolate. Elevated ammonium seawater was prepared by adding ammonium chloride to filtered seawater, and the final concentration of ammonium chloride was 100 μmol L −1 . Coral nubbins were randomly divided into two groups: control (NH4_Control) and stress (NH4). The coral nubbins in the NH4_Control group were placed in 25-L tanks (n = 2 per tank) containing filtered seawater, while the coral nubbins in the NH4 group were placed in the elevated ammonium seawater. After 12 h, all coral nubbins were sampled with two biological repetitions in each group. To each sample, 1 mL Trizol reagent (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA) was added, and the sample was stored in liquid nitrogen immediately for RNA extraction.

div.head: Construction and sequencing of transcriptome libraries
div.p: Total RNA was isolated from each coral sample using Trizol reagent (Invitrogen) according to the manufacturer's protocol. The harvested total RNA was quantified by Nanodrop 2000 (Thermo Scientific) at 260/280 nm (ratio N 2.0), and its integrity was checked with Agilent Bioanalyzer (Agilent Technologies). The pair-end fragment library (2 × 100 bp) was constructed and sequenced on the Illumina Hiseq4000 platform according to the manufacturer's instructions (BGI, Shenzhen, China). The raw sequencing reads were submitted to NCBI Short Read Archive under accession number SRR2757326.

div.head: Assembly of coral transcripts
div.p: Raw reads obtained from Illumina sequencing were processed by the Fastx-Toolkit pipeline (http://hannonlab.cshl.edu/fastx_toolkit/ index.html) to summarize data production, evaluate sequencing quality, and remove low-quality reads and adaptor sequences. The obtained clean reads from four libraries were merged to assemble the transcripts using the Trinity software (http://trinityrnaseq.github.io/) (Haas et al., 2013). The redundant transcripts were identified and removed using TGICL software (http://sourceforge.net/projects/tgicl/) (Pertea et al., 2003).

The coral and zooxanthella transcripts were further differentiated using the BLAST software. Because the genomes of the coral Acropora digitifera and the zooxanthella Symbiodinium minutum have been sequenced (Shinzato et al., 2011;Shoguchi et al., 2013), their protein sequences were downloaded and merged. After a protein BLAST database was constructed, the assembled transcripts were aligned to the protein database through BLASTX algorithm (evalu = 1 − e5, max_target_seqs = 1). The transcripts whose encoded proteins shared high sequence similarity with S. minutum proteins were regarded as zooxanthella-derived transcripts, while the transcripts whose encoded proteins shared high sequence similarity with the proteins from A. digitifera were referred to as the transcripts derived from the coral P. damicornis. The coral transcripts and corresponding genes were used in the subsequent function annotation and reads mapping.

div.head: Identification of differentially expressed genes
div.p: The assembled coral transcripts served as the reference sequence in the reads mapping, and a GTF annotation file was constructed using a homemade Perl script. All pair-end reads were aligned using TopHat software. Cufflinks software was used to assemble transcripts, estimate their abundances, and identify the differentially expressed genes between the NH4_Control and NH4 groups (Trapnell et al., 2012). The RNA-Seq data were analyzed using an R package of CummeRbund.

div.head: GO enrichment of differentially expressed genes
div.p: Similar coding regions of the assembled coral transcripts were extracted, and their encoded proteins were then retrieved using TransDecoder software (http://transdecoder.github.io/). These transcripts and proteins were aligned by local BLASTX and BLASTP search to SwissProt and Uniref90 databases (max_target_seqs =1). The potential domains of these proteins were predicted through a Pfam search. The obtained alignment results were further parsed by Trinotate software (http:// trinotate.github.io/) for function annotation and GO term assigning.

After the identification of differentially expressed genes, the lists of significantly upregulated and downregulated genes were obtained. Their GO enrichment analysis was implemented by the hypergeometric test with a filter value of 0.01. The differentially expressed genes were selected as the test set, while all other genes were considered as the reference set. The significantly overrepresented and underrepresented GO terms were identified from the test set using BiNGO tool (Maere et al., 2005).

div.head: Construction and sequencing of transcriptome libraries
div.p: In the present study, the RNA-seq method was used for the analysis of transcriptome from the stony coral P. damicornis. A total of four transcriptome pair-end libraries were constructed from the coral after the exposure to elevated ammonium seawater, including the NH4_Control and NH4 groups (two repeats for each group), and they were sequenced to the saturated level by Illumina Hiseq4000 platform to compare the gene expression abundance and difference. After filtering low-quality sequences and adaptor sequences, there were 121,366,983 pair-end reads with a length of 2 × 100 bp obtained from all the libraries, including 30,274,934 and 30,365,662 reads from the NH4_Control libraries, and 30,581,298 and 30,145,089 reads from the NH4 libraries.

div.head: Transcript assembling and differentiation
div.p: The transcripts from the coral-zooxanthellae symbionts were assembled using Trinity software, and the coral transcripts were retrieved using BLASTX algorithm. The merged libraries were submitted to Trinity software, and 297,221 transcripts (N50 = 1831 bp) were obtained, corresponding to 209,337 genes (N50 = 1435 bp). After the alignment to the BLAST database constructed from the proteins of the coral A. digitifera and the zooxanthella S. minutum, 77,199 transcripts (42,399 genes) shared high homology with A. digitifera, and N50 values of the transcripts and genes were 2803 and 2460 bp, respectively. Further, 84,069 transcripts (N50 = 1826 bp) shared high homology with S. minutum; these transcripts were from 54,874 genes (N50 = 1653 bp) ( Fig. 1).

div.head: Estimation of gene expression abundance
div.p: High-quality reads were aligned with TopHat software by using the reference sequence built from the assembled coral transcripts. The mapping rates ranged from 40.00% to 44.90% for the four libraries, and the unique mapping rates ranged from 37.60% to 42.30% (Table 1). Gene expression abundance was analyzed using Cufflinks software, and the expression level of each gene was calculated by the method of FPKM (Fragments Per Kilobase of exon per Million fragments mapped). The overall expression level of genes was estimated using the CummeRbund package. The principal component analysis plot of the gene expression levels in the two groups of samples revealed that the replicates were more highly correlated within the samples than between the samples (Fig. 2), and a dendrogram of Jensen-Shannon distances showed similarity in gene expression level in the four groups and good parallelism between the two replicates in each group (Fig. S1). The numbers of genes with FPKM N 100 were 358 and 445 in the NH4_Control and NH4 groups, respectively. There were 10,940 and 10,177 low abundant genes with FPKM b 1 and 769 and 12,010 genes with FPKM = 0 in the NH4_Control and NH4 groups, respectively (Table S1).

div.head: Identification of differentially expressed genes
div.p: In this study, the differentially expressed coral genes were analyzed using Cufflinks software. After calibrating the library, the expression level of 42,399 coral genes was compared between the NH4_Control and NH4 groups. The comparison revealed 6572 differentially expressed genes (Table S2). Two lists of differentially expressed genes were obtained, including the lists of significantly upregulated and downregulated genes, and they included 1015 and 5557 differentially expressed genes, respectively (Fig. 3).

div.head: GO annotation of differentially expressed genes
div.p: The expression level of 1015 coral genes in the NH4 group was higher than that in the NH4_Control group. The GO term enrichment analysis of these genes was completed at the multiple GO levels (Fig. 4). There were 22 major overrepresented GO terms assigned to the Biological Process category, including response to chemical stimulus (GO:0042221), response to organic substance (GO:0010033), regulation of molecular function (GO:0065009), positive regulation of molecular function (GO:0044093), positive regulation of multicellular organismal process (GO:0051240), regulation of binding (GO:0051098), regulation of transcription factor activity (GO:0051090), regulation of transcription regulator activity (GO:0090046), death (GO:0016265), cell death (GO:0008219), regulation of cell death (GO:0010941), negative regulation of cell death (GO:0060548), induction of programmed cell death (GO:0012502), regulation of programmed cell death (GO:0043067), positive regulation of cell death (GO:0010942), programmed cell death (GO:0012501), positive regulation of programmed cell death (GO:0043068), apoptosis (GO:0006915), induction of apoptosis (GO:0006917), regulation of apoptosis (GO:0042981), induction of apoptosis by oxidation stress (GO:0008631), and tissue remodeling (GO:0048771). It is worth noting that the GO term response to chemical stimulus was the most common annotation term, which accounted for 17.5% of the total significantly upregulated genes after exposure to elevated ammonium. Besides, there were molecular transducer activity (GO:0060089) and signal transducer activity (GO:0004871) in the Molecular Function category (Table S3).

There were 5557 differentially expressed genes whose expression level in the NH4 group was lower than that in the NH4_Control group. The GO term enrichment analysis of these genes was completed at the multiple GO levels in the Biological Process category, and 95 overrepresented and underrepresented GO terms were observed (Tables S4 and S5). The top 10 overrepresented GO terms contained nucleobase, nucleoside, nucleotide and nucleic acid metabolic process (GO:0006139, 9.69E − 31), nucleic acid metabolic process (GO:0090304, 1.39E − 30), RNA metabolic process (GO:0016070, 3.26E − 30), gene expression (GO:0010467, 3.21E − 29), cellular macromolecule metabolic process (GO:0044260, 2.83E − 24), cellular nitrogen compound metabolic process (GO:0034641, 4.88E − 24), cellular macromolecule biosynthetic process (GO:0034645, 7.72E − 24), macromolecule biosynthetic process (GO:0009059, 4.27E − 23), nitrogen compound metabolic process (GO:0006807, 4.30E−21), and cellular metabolic process (GO:0044237, 4.85E− 21). Furthermore, G-protein-coupled receptor protein signaling pathway (GO:0007186, 4.41E−41), cell surface receptor-linked signaling pathway (GO:0007166, 1.20E − 24), regulation of cyclic nucleotide metabolic process (GO:0030799, 3.78E − 24), regulation of cAMP metabolic process (GO:0030814, 6.33E − 24), regulation of lyase activity (GO:0051339, 3.26E−22), regulation of cyclase activity (GO:0031279, 4.78E − 22), regulation of cyclic nucleotide biosynthetic process (GO:0030802, 6.83E − 22), regulation of nucleotide biosynthetic process (GO:0030808, 6.83E− 22), regulation of adenylate cyclase activity (GO:0045761, 6.99E−22), and regulation of cAMP biosynthetic process (GO:0030817, 3.62E − 21) were the top 10 underrepresented GO terms for all significantly downregulated genes (Fig. 5).

div.head: Induction-related genes of apoptosis and programmed cell death
div.p: For 1015 significantly upregulated genes, there were 13 GO terms related to apoptosis and cell death among 24 overrepresented GO terms. Furthermore, 3 overrepresented GO terms were observed to be related to the induction of apoptosis and programmed cell death, including induction of apoptosis (GO:0006917), induction of apoptosis by oxidation stress (GO:0008631), and induction of programmed cell death (GO:0,012,502). There were 14 genes (TR74697 | c0_g1,

, and TR69530 | c0_g1) within the three GO terms, and they included one caspase, five bcl-2-like proteins, two tumor necrosis factor receptor superfamily member, two CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein, one zinc finger protein, one RING-box protein, one proline dehydrogenase, and one SH2 domain-containing protein genes (Table 2).

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Unicellular zooxanthellae are harbored in the intracellular vacuoles of stony coral's gastrodermal (endodermal) tissue, and zooxanthellae and coral as symbionts gain benefit from each other (Ganot et al., 2011). In the present study, the transcriptomes of the coral P. damicornis were sequenced after exposure to elevated ammonium. There were 121,366,983 pair-end reads with a length of × 100 bp, and 297,221 transcripts were assembled and obtained from 209,337 genes. These transcripts were derived from P. damicornis symbionts, including the eukaryote coral, zooxanthellae, and a possible fungus (Mayfield et al., 2014;Vidal-Dupiol et al., 2014;Vidal-Dupiol et al., 2013). The BLAST search method was used to obtain the transcripts of the coral P. damicornis, which had been used in the selection of coral transcripts from P. damicornis and Porites australiensis symbionts (Shinzato et al., 2014;Vidal-Dupiol et al., 2013). It was observed that 77,199 transcripts from 42,399 genes shared high homology with A. digitifera than with S. minutum, demonstrating that these genes should be from P. damicornis. The number of assembled genes was consistent with the result of previous studies, in which 42,859 and 50,877 genes were assembled from P. damicornis (Mayfield et al., 2014;Vidal-Dupiol et al., 2013). This suggested that the assembling and differentiation of coral transcripts were reliable in the present study, and the obtained coral transcripts and genes could be used in the subsequent expression abundance analysis. Furthermore, 84,069 transcripts from 54,874 genes shared high homology with S. minutum. Because the species and type of the symbiotic zooxanthellae were unclear in the experimental coral P. damicornis, its transcriptome response could not be analyzed in the present study.

The transcriptome libraries of the stony coral P. damicornis under elevated ammonium were sequenced to understand its transcriptional response to the high level of nutrients and offer fundamental new clues to reveal the environmental adaption mechanism of stony corals. The relative dispersion and parallelism between two repeats in each group resulted in higher statistical confidence in the transcriptome comparison, and such high-throughput RNA-Seq analysis intrigued us to identify a large number of differentially expressed genes under elevated ammonium levels. There were 6572 differentially expressed Fig. 3. The number of total assembled genes, differentially expressed genes, significantly upregulated genes (increased DEGs), and significantly downregulated genes (decreased DEGs).

genes identified in the comparison of NH4 versus NH4_Control group, including 1015 significantly upregulated genes and 5557 significantly downregulated genes. This result was comparable to the previous study, in which 3126 significantly upregulated genes and 11,735 significantly downregulated genes were identified from the heat-stressed coral P. damicornis (Vidal-Dupiol et al., 2014). These RNA-Seq analyses demonstrated that the transcriptome is remodeled in the coral P. damicornis under different environmental stress conditions to maintain symbiosis and improve adaptability. The results also favor that the RNA-Seq analysis for transcriptome profiling can be used as a robust and reliable strategy to assess transcriptional responses of the coral species to various environmental conditions, and as a powerful approach to provide the molecular basis for environmental adaption.

To further understand the coral physiological activities regulated by these differentially expressed genes, their GO enrichment was analyzed using BiNGO software. There were 1015 significantly upregulated genes in the coral P. damicornis after exposure to elevated ammonium, and 24 major overrepresented GO terms were observed at the multiple GO levels. The GO terms response to chemical stimulus (GO:0042221) and response to organic substance (GO:0010033) were overrepresented significantly, which accounted for 17.5% and 11.8% of the total significantly upregulated genes under elevated ammonium, respectively. This revealed that the coral P. damicornis could initiate physiological reaction to adapt to or resist elevated ammonium levels. Furthermore, it was worth noting that there were 13 GO terms related to apoptosis and cell death among the 24 overrepresented GO terms. Some results similar to those reported by Kuntz et al. (2005) were observed wherein a high level of nutrients induced bleaching and partial mortality of Montastraea annularis and Agaricia tenuifolia (Kuntz et al., 2005). The result of the present study showed that cell apoptosis and death were induced and regulated in the coral P. damicornis under elevated ammonium, which might have resulted from intracellular oxidation stress. It was suspected that the intracellular oxidation stress might attribute to the photosynthesis of more symbiotic zooxanthellae, because the population density of zooxanthellae increase significantly in the coral P. damicornis under elevated concentrations of ammonium (Hill et al., 2014;Hoegh-Guldberg, 1994;Muller-Parker et al., 1994). These results suggested that elevated ammonium could induce apoptosis and cell death in the coral P. damicornis.

Among all the overrepresented GO terms of significantly upregulated genes, three terms were related to the induction of apoptosis and cell death. The genes within these three GO terms contained one caspase, five bcl-2-like proteins, and two tumor necrosis factor receptor superfamily member genes. Because it has been proved that the activation of tumor necrosis factor pathway could increase caspase activity, cause apoptotic blebbing and cell death, and finally induce bleaching in the coral A. digitifera (Quistad et al., 2014), the result of the present study showed that the stony coral P. damicornis could also have a similar molecular mechanism. Combining the results from other previous studies (Hawkins et al., 2013;Liu et al., 2000;Zmasek et al., 2007), it was speculated that more oxygen free radicals from the photosynthesis of symbiotic zooxanthellae triggered the tumor necrosis factor pathway in the coral P. damicornis, and it further activated the apoptosis and cell death pathway mediated by caspase and bcl-2-like proteins. These results suggest that elevated ammonium could induce apoptosis and cell death through the tumor necrosis factor and caspase-bcl-2 pathways in the coral P. damicornis.

For the 5557 significantly downregulated genes, there were 95 overrepresented and 67 underrepresented GO terms in the Biological Process category. Among the overrepresented GO terms, the most significantly downregulated genes were from metabolic process (GO:0008152), while the genes with the least enrichment p value were from nucleobase, nucleoside, nucleotide, and nucleic acid metabolic process (GO:0006139, 9.69E−31). Among the top 10 overrepresented GO terms, gene expression (GO:0010467) was the only term unrelated to the nucleic acid metabolism. Further, G-protein-coupled receptor protein signaling pathway (GO:0007186) had the least enrichment p value (4.406E−41) among the 67 underrepresented GO terms, and other eight top 10 underrepresented GO terms were related to the G-protein-coupled receptor protein signaling pathway. The results showed that the nucleic acid metabolic process and gene expression were restrained distinctly in the coral P. damicornis under elevated ammonium, while the Gprotein-coupled receptor protein signaling pathway was also regulated to optimize the adaptability. The G-protein-coupled receptor signaling pathway mediates most of the physiological responses to hormones, neurotransmitters, and environmental stimulants, and regulates gene expression and cellular activities through the downward pathway, including second messenger and three classical signaling pathways (Rosenbaum et al., 2009). Therefore, the regulation of the nucleic acid metabolic process, gene expression, and G-proteincoupled receptor signaling pathway further proved the remodeling of the transcriptome in the coral P. damicornis under elevated ammonium levels, which might also result in the upregulated expression of genes related to cell apoptosis and death.

All these results indicated a dynamic adaption process of the coral P. damicornis to elevated ammonium. When the coral P. damicornis encountered elevated environmental ammonium, the diffusion of ammonium into coral cells would break the nitrogen limit of the symbiotic zooxanthellae and improve its population density, resulting in the production of more oxygen by zooxanthellae photosynthesis and more oxygen free radicals. These excessive oxygen free radicals caused intracellular oxidation stress in the coral cells at 12 h after the exposure to elevated ammonium, and activated the tumor necrosis factor pathway to induce coral apoptosis and cell death through caspase and bcl-2 and thus reduced the harm caused by oxygen free radicals. The G-protein-coupled receptor signaling pathway was also activated to regulate the gene expression. The symbiotic balance between the coral and zooxanthellae was broken in P. damicornis, and the rebalance might occur after 12 h of exposure to elevated ammonium.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at http://dx. doi.org/10.1016/j.marpolbul.2016.08.036.

div.head: Acknowledgments
div.p: The authors are grateful to all the laboratory staff for their continuous technical advice and helpful discussion. This research was supported by the Scientific Research Foundation (kyqd1554) and Midwestern Construction Projects (ZXBJH-XK006) from Hainan University, and grants from the Natural Science Foundation from Hainan Province (No. 20164158 to ZZ.).
